timeline.bodyText: What do you think of making this a filter and allowing Regular Expressions? It should maybe add one or two lines to this PR, but make this feature much easier to use (we don't have to specify the full test name) and more flexible (we could run a group of tests).
timeline.author: schmidt-sebastian

timeline.bodyText: If you go with regular expression approach, this could be System.getProperty(EXCLUSIVE_PROPERTY, ".*"), in which case you can always apply the filter.
timeline.author: schmidt-sebastian

replies.bodyText: This won't work though because I need to be able to distinguish between the property being set or not being set.  The reason is that if it is set then exclusiveMode must be set to true and if it is not then it must be left alone.  By using a default value I cannot know if .* was specified explicitly or was the default value.
replies.author: dconeybe

timeline.bodyText: We should try not to import more Guava dependencies, unless we want to make an exception for tests (cc @wu-hui).
timeline.author: schmidt-sebastian

replies.bodyText: In my opinion, and exception for tests makes a lot of sense since there are no downstream dependencies on the test artifacts that could result in dependency mismatch conflicts.  Moreover, this class already imports com.google.common.collect.Sets from guava, so this is not a net new dependency on guava.
replies.author: dconeybe

replies.bodyText:
I am OK to import Guava in tests.
And thanks for adding this, will be really handy to try to debug a specific test.
replies.author: wu-hui

timeline.message: Use a regex instead of an exact match for spec test filtering.

timeline.author: schmidt-sebastian
schmidt-sebastian

replies.bodyText:
A Matcher object must be created with a string against which to match.  So we must create a new Matcher object for each test name.
https://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/regex/Pattern#matcher(java.lang.CharSequence)
replies.author: dconeybe
